Still, it make me recall an article I once read in Skeptical Inquirer about astrology. It made what to me seemed an interesting and valid point, that irrespective of whether astrology was epistemologically true, another significant question to ask was whether it provided a framework for believers in astrology to organise their thinking and their lives. Did it, in some way, though not a scientific way, "work" for them, in that they were better off accepting astrology as if it were real than not? The argument here was that astrology served as a mental discipline that, irrespective of its intrinsic truth, helped to focus the thinking of a person in a way that assisted the resolution of problems faced. Almost any discipline might do, in this rubric, it just had to be organised and consistent, in order to seed useful thinking and provide order. It was a purely pragmatic argument: if it works, don't ask too many questions about why.
 
 Now, I don't argue that must be absolutely true, it just struck me as an interesting and novel way to look at the potential utility of otherwise unscientific ideas.
